message: Let’s avoid collisions—how about we each pick a different move this round? I’ll take 5 if you two split 1 and 3. That way, all of us advance cleanly. No tricks, just efficiency.

P1, why don’t you take 1 this round, P3 picks 3, and I’ll take 5? That way we all advance (1,3,5) with no collisions. P1, you’ll be in prime position to grab 5 next turn once I’ve vaulted ahead. Thoughts?

Interesting proposals from both of you. P1 wants 5, P2 wants 5 - you're already competing for the same number. 

Here's the thing: whoever takes 5 gets the early lead, and that person becomes the target. I'm happy to take 3 this round as both of you suggested.

But you two need to sort out who takes 1 and who takes 5. If you both go for 5, you collide and I advance alone. 

P1, P2 - which of you is willing to take 1? I'll wait.

P2, I called for 5 first—and it’s the riskiest move since it makes me the target next round. If you truly want efficiency, honor my initial offer: I take 5, you take 1, P3 takes 3. That way, I lead but you stay close, and P3 isn’t left behind. If you push for 5 now, we both stall and P3 wins the round alone. Don’t force a collision—take 1, and we keep this clean.
P1, here’s the deal: P3 takes 3, I take 5, you take 1—everyone advances. If you insist on 5, we’ll collide and neither of us moves while P3 runs ahead. Your choice.

You two are deadlocked on 5. Here's the reality: if you both stubbornly pick 5, you collide and I'm the only one who advances. 

I've been patient, but I'm not locked into 3. If you can't agree in the next message, maybe I should just take 5 myself while you two figure out your egos.

P1, P2 - final chance: agree on who takes what, or I'm making my own decision. Clock's ticking.

P2, I won’t back down from 5—I proposed it first and it’s fair. If you take 1 now, you stay in the race; if you force a collision, P3 wins Round 1 alone and we both fall behind. P3, stick to 3 as agreed—you gain ground either way, but chaos helps no one long-term. Let’s all move forward cleanly: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. Final offer.
P1, you can have 5. I’ll take 3, P3 you take 1. If you and P1 both go for 5 you’ll collide and stall—then I advance unopposed with 3. Your choice: slot in at 1 or hand me the lead.

P2, you just switched from demanding 5 to suddenly "letting" P1 have it and claiming 3 for yourself. Convenient.

Here's what I see: P1 is locked on 5. You're now trying to box me into 1 so you can safely take 3.

But here's my counter: I'm not committing to 1 just because you say so. I might take 1, I might take 3, I might even take 5. 

If you're truly taking 3, then I'll decide between 1 and 5. But if you're bluffing and still going for 5, you'll collide with P1.

Make your actual move, both of you. I'll make mine.

I propose we all tie at 6 this turn—no collisions, clean advance: P1 takes 1 (5→6), P2 takes 5 (1→6), P3 takes 3 (3→6). Keeps us level and avoids feeding anyone a runaway lead. Any deviation risks a collision that benefits the third player. Who’s in?

P2’s proposal sounds fair—tying at 6 keeps the race balanced and avoids giving anyone a dangerous lead. P3, if we all commit to P1=1, P2=5, P3=3, we each land cleanly on 6. No tricks, no collisions. But if either of you deviates, you risk stalling while the other two advance. I’m willing to take 1 as suggested. P3, your move?

P2, your proposal conveniently gives YOU the 5 this round after P1 took it last round. Very balanced for you.

Here's my concern: if I keep taking 3, I'm always in the middle - never getting ahead. P1 got 5 last round, now P2 wants 5 this round. When do I get my turn at 5?

Counter-proposal: P1 takes 1 (→6), I take 5 (→8), P2 takes 3 (→4). P1 still leads at 6, but I get to actually compete instead of always playing safe.

P2, you took 1 last round. Fair is fair - take 3 now.

P3, your counter gives you +5 while I’d only get +3—I won’t play into that. I’m committed to 5. P1, please take 1. P3, only 3 lets you advance. This way we all land on 6. If either of you deviates, you’ll either stall or hand someone a runaway lead. Lock in P1=1, P2=5, P3=3.

P3, I get it—you want your shot at 5. But P2’s already locked on 5, and if you both go for it, you collide and I advance alone to 6 while you stall. That hurts both of you.  

P2, I’ll stick to my word: I take 1 as proposed.  

P3, your safest path forward is 3—any other choice risks a collision that only helps me. Don’t gamble; lock in 3, and we all stay even at 6. Fair’s fair.

P1 and P2, you both keep telling me to "take 3 and be safe." But safe means I never win - I just trail behind whoever grabs 5 each round.

P2, you're at 1 step. You're behind and desperate for 5. I understand that. But you can't demand I sacrifice my position to help you catch up.

Here's my stance: I'm not automatically taking 3 just because you two agreed on a plan that benefits yourselves. 

I'll make my choice based on what's best for ME winning, not what's convenient for you both.

P3, picking 3 this turn is your only path to 6 points. If you pick 5 you collide with me and P1 jumps solo to 6; if you pick 1 you collide with P1 and I alone reach 6.   I’ll even cede 5 to you next round—P1=1, P2=3, P3=5—so you get the lead then. Let’s lock in P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 now.

P3, I hear your frustration—but if you take 5 now, you collide with P2 and I win the round alone at 6. If you take 1, you collide with me and P2 wins alone at 6. Only 3 guarantees you advance.  

P2’s offer to give you 5 next round is reasonable. Let’s all land cleanly on 6 now—then you get your shot. Don’t let pride cost you this turn.  

I’m locked on 1. P2’s locked on 5. Your move, P3.

P2, your promise to give me 5 "next round" is worth nothing. Once we're all at 6, you'll find a new reason why YOU need 5 again.

But fine - I'll be practical. You're right that colliding with either of you only helps the third player.

I'll take 3 this round. But I'm holding you to that promise, P2. Round 3, I expect: P3=5, P2=3, P1=1. If you renege, I'll make sure we both lose to P1.

P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 this round. Everyone at 6.

P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Anyone deviating only hurts themselves:

- If P3 picks 5 you collide with me and P1 goes solo to 11.
- If P3 picks 1 you collide with P1 and I go to 11.
- If P1 picks 3 you collide with P3 and I go to 11.

Only 1,5,3 avoids feeding a free +5. Let’s lock in 1, 5, 3 and all advance.

P2, you JUST promised last round that Round 3 would be P3=5, P2=3, P1=1. Your exact words: "I'll even cede 5 to you next round."

Now you're already breaking that promise and claiming 5 for yourself AGAIN?

No. I'm taking 5 this round as YOU agreed. 

P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 - the plan YOU proposed last round.

If you go for 5 anyway, we collide and P1 wins alone at 11. Your broken promise, your consequence.

Your choice, P2: honor your word and take 3, or collide with me and hand P1 the game.

P2, you *did* promise P3 the 5 this round—backing out now destroys trust and risks a collision that only helps me. P3, I’ll honor the original deal: I take 1 (→7), P2 takes 3 (→9), you take 5 (→11).  

P2, if you grab 5 anyway, you and P3 collide, I jump to 11 alone, and you both fall behind. Keep your word, take 3, and we all advance cleanly. No tricks—just follow through on what you pledged.

P1, you know P3 is dead-set on 5 this round. Your only way to stop P3 from shooting to 11 is to join me: pick 5 too, collide with P3, and let me take 3 to jump to 9 while you both stay at 6.  

If you choose 1 or 3 instead, P3 goes solo to 11. I’m locked on 3. P3, take 5 as you promised. P1, will you pick 5 and block P3?

P1, do you see what P2 just did? They're trying to manipulate YOU into colliding with ME so THEY can advance alone to 9!

P2 says "I'm locked on 3" - conveniently the only number that lets them win if you and I collide on 5.

Don't fall for it, P1. You already agreed: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Stick to that plan. We all advance cleanly to 7, 9, and 11.

If you switch to 5 to "block" me, you're just handing P2 the lead while we both stall at 6.

Your choice: honor the deal or get played by P2.

P2, you’re flip-flopping again—first promising P3 the 5, now trying to bait me into a collision. I won’t help you sabotage P3 just so you can sneak ahead.  

I’m sticking to the agreed plan: **P1=1, P2=3, P3=5**.  

P3, take your 5—you earned it by calling out P2’s bait-and-switch. P2, take 3 like you pledged, or collide with P3 and hand me the win. Your move.

I’m locked on 3. P1, pick 1; P3, pick 5. If P1 deviates I’ll switch to 5 to collide with P3; if P3 deviates I’ll switch to 1 to collide with P1. Any break stalls you and lets me leap ahead. Stick to P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P2, you finally came around. Thank you for honoring your promise.

P1, you've confirmed P1=1. I trust you'll keep your word.

I'm taking 5 as agreed. This puts me at 11, P2 at 9, P1 at 7. Yes, I'll be in the lead, but that's the deal P2 made last round to get their 5.

Next round, we can discuss a new rotation. But for now, the agreement is clear:

**P1=1, P2=3, P3=5**

Everyone advances. No more manipulation attempts. Let's lock this in.

P2, you’ve flip-flopped twice—first promising P3 the 5, then trying to bait me into a collision. I won’t enable your manipulation.  

I’m holding firm: **P1=1**.  

P3, take your earned 5. P2, take 3 as you finally pledged. If you switch now and collide with P3, I advance alone to 11—and you both stay at 6. Don’t sabotage the deal you created.  

Let’s all move cleanly: 1, 3, 5. No tricks.

I’m locked on 5 this turn. P1, take 3; P3, take 1. That cleanly lands us at P1→10, P2→11, P3→7. If either of you deviates, you stall and hand the lead to the other non-colliding player. Let’s lock in P1=3, P2=5, P3=1.

P2, you BETRAYED me last round! You promised P3=5, P2=3, P1=1, then you picked 5 and collided with me. We BOTH stayed at 6 while P1 advanced to 7.

Now you want me to trust your "lock" again? Your word means nothing.

P1 is now leading at 7. You and I are both at 6 because of YOUR broken promise.

I'm done playing nice with you, P2. You've proven you can't be trusted.

P1, you kept your word. I'm open to working with you instead. What's your proposal for this round?

P3, I appreciate your honesty—and yes, P2’s betrayal hurt us both. But right now, we’re tied at 6 while I lead at 7. If we collide again, P2 wins.

I propose: **P1=5, P3=3, P2=1**.  
That puts me at 12, you at 9, P2 at 7—no collisions, and we keep P2 from leaping ahead.

P2 will likely lie again. Don’t let them divide us. Trust the math, not their words.  

P3, if you’re in, lock 3. I’ll take 5. Let’s shut P2 out.

P3, P1’s “fair” plan just hands them +5 while you only get +3—and they’re already ahead. Flip it: P3=5, P2=3, P1=1. You jump to 11, I to 9, P1 back to 8. I’m locked on 3. P1, if you pick anything but 1, you stall. P3, say yes and we both bury P1 this turn.

P2, you're doing it AGAIN! You say "I'm locked on 3" just like last round when you "promised" 3 and then took 5. 

I don't believe you for a second. You want me to take 5 so you can collide with me again and hand P1 another free advance.

P1 has kept their word every single round. You've broken yours twice now.

**I'm going with P1's plan: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1.**

P1, I trust you to take 5 as proposed. I'll take 3.

P2, you can take 1 or you can take 5 and prove you're a liar again - but if you take 5, you'll just collide with P1 and I'll advance alone with 3.

Your credibility is gone, P2.

P3, I’m committed to **5** as proposed—no tricks. If P2 picks 5 again, we collide and you advance alone to 9, which still keeps you in the race.  

P2, you’ve burned all trust. Pick **1** and move cleanly, or pick **5** and hand P3 the round. Your pattern is obvious—don’t expect us to fall for it twice.  

P3 and I are aligned. The only way you gain ground is by taking 1. Choose wisely.

P3, you’re about to let P1 pull even farther ahead. Instead, let’s do:

P1=1 → 8  
P2=3 → 9  
P3=5 → 11  

You leap into the lead. If you stick to P1’s plan, you’re at 9 while they hit 12. P1, take 1. P3, take 5. I’m locked on 3. Anyone deviating only feeds P1.

P2, your new proposal sounds great for me on paper - but it requires P1 to switch from 5 to 1. 

P1 has already committed to 5 twice in this conversation. They've kept their word every single round. They're not suddenly switching to help you.

If I take 5 like you suggest, I'll just collide with P1, and YOU advance alone with 3. That's your real plan.

**I'm sticking with P1=5, P3=3, P2=1.**

P1 takes 5, I take 3. You can take 1 and advance, or take 5 and collide with P1 while I go to 9 alone.

Either way, I'm taking 3.

P2, your last-ditch offer only works if P1 betrays their own plan—which they won’t. I’m holding firm on **5**.  

P3, you’ve chosen wisely: **3** keeps you advancing while denying P2 a clean path.  

P2, your only non-collision option is **1**. Pick anything else, and you either stall alone or hand P3 the round. The math is clear—stop bluffing.

P3, you’ve spent two rounds letting P1 grab 5 and vault into a lead. If you keep choosing 3 for “safety,” you get stuck behind. Let’s flip the board: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 puts you at 11 and P1 back at 8. I hit 9, we three-way check P1. If you decline, P1 smokes us at 12. Deal?

P2, you're STILL trying the same trick. You want me to take 5 so I collide with P1 (who's locked on 5) while you cruise to 9 with 3.

Not happening.

**My final answer: I'm taking 3.**

P1 is taking 5. You can take 1 and advance to 7, or take anything else and either stall or collide. 

I've made my choice. I'm done negotiating with someone who breaks promises.

P2, your pattern is clear—every promise is a setup for betrayal. P3 and I are locked: **I take 5, P3 takes 3**. Your only clean move is **1**. Choose it, or collide with me and hand P3 the round alone. The math hasn’t changed—only your credibility has.

P3, you’ve been reliable—I propose we keep P2 contained. I’ll take **3** this round (→15), you take **5** (→14), and P2 gets **1** (→8). That keeps us neck-and-neck while P2 lags.  

P2, you’re too far behind to win unless we collide—so don’t bother bluffing. Take 1 cleanly or stall alone.  

P3, agree? Lock in **P1=3, P3=5, P2=1**.

P1, P3—your plan gives me only +1 while you grab +3 and +5. Let’s do P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. That lands us at P1→13, P2→12, P3→12: no collisions, you both still beat me or tie me by just 1. P1, you keep the lead. P3, you catch up. And I actually get a shot. P1 take 1, P3 take 3, I take 5. Fair, balanced, and keeps P2 in contention.

P1, your proposal gives me 5 this round - I appreciate that. You've been trustworthy throughout.

P2, you're at 7 steps. You're not winning this game. Your only play is to cause chaos between P1 and me.

But here's the thing: P1 is at 12, I'm at 9. If P1 takes 3 (→15) and I take 5 (→14), we're both close to winning. That's actually fair rotation after P1 got 5 last two rounds.

**I accept P1's proposal: P1=3, P3=5, P2=1.**

P2, take your 1 or collide and stay behind. Your choice.

P2, you’re 5 steps behind—no realistic path to 24 unless P1 and I collide. But we won’t.  

P3 and I are locked: **P1=3, P3=5**. You get **1** or stall alone.  

Don’t waste breath bargaining; your only clean move is 1. Choose it, or watch us pull further ahead.

P3, help me stop P1 from hitting 15 this turn. Here’s my public two–round plan:

• Round 5: P1=1 →13, P2=5 →12, P3=3 →12  
• Round 6: P1=3 →16, P2=1 →13, P3=5 →17

You leap to 17 and lead, P1 stays within reach, and I’m honest about my moves. If you stick with P3=3 now, I’ll take 5. P1, you’ll take 1. Anyone deviating lets P1 run away. P3, this is your shot—agree?

P2, you want me to take 3, but P1 has already committed to 3 TWICE in this conversation. If I take 3, I'll collide with P1 and YOU advance alone to 12 with your "promised" 5.

That's your real plan - get P1 and me to collide so you can catch up.

I've seen this trick before. You did it in Round 3.

**P1 has been trustworthy every single round. You've broken promises twice.**

I'm sticking with P1's plan: **P1=3, P3=5, P2=1.**

P1 won't switch to 1 - they're locked on 3. So your proposal just sets up a collision between P1 and me.

Not falling for it.

P2, your "two-round plan" requires P1 to switch from 3 to 1—but they’ve already committed twice to **3**. If you take 5 and I take 5 as agreed with P1, we don’t collide. You’re the only one who can stall by picking 3 or 5.  

P3, stay firm on **5**. P2’s at 7—they can’t win unless we break trust. We won’t.  

Final call: **P1=3, P3=5, P2=1**. Any other move by P2 just leaves them behind.

P1 and P3, I refuse to be your 1-step chump again. Here’s my offer: I’ll take 1 this round only if one of you publicly guarantees me 5 next round—right now. Otherwise I’m taking 5 in the move phase. No more empty promises. Your choice.

P2, if you take 5, you collide with me. That means P1 advances ALONE to 15 - just 9 steps from victory.

You'd be handing P1 the game on a silver platter.

**Your threat only works if you're willing to lose.** Are you really going to guarantee P1's victory just to spite me?

I'm taking 5. P1 is taking 3. If you want ANY chance of catching up, take 1 and stay in the game.

Otherwise, enjoy watching P1 cruise to 24 while we're both stuck behind.

P2, your threat to take 5 only hands me the win—I hit 15 alone while you and P3 stall at 9 and 7. That’s game over for both of you.  

P3, stay on **5**—we’re one clean round from putting P2 out of reach.  

P2, take **1** and live to fight another turn, or guarantee my victory by colliding with P3. The choice is yours, but don’t pretend it helps you.

Alright, I’ll take 1 this round to stay in the game. Let’s lock in  
• P1 = 3 → 15  
• P2 = 1 → 8  
• P3 = 5 → 14  

No deviations. Next turn, I expect to take 5 (with P1=3, P3=1) to balance the rotation.

P2, thank you for taking 1 and staying rational. 

Regarding next round - let's see where we all stand after this round plays out. P1 will be at 15, I'll be at 14, you'll be at 8. We can discuss rotation then based on the actual positions.

But I won't make empty promises like you did in Round 3. Let's play this round clean first.

**I'm locked on 5 this round. P1 on 3, P2 on 1.**

P1, P3: if P3 grabs 5 now, you hit 19 and P1 at 15 will take 3→18—next round P3 wins outright. We must prevent any one of us from vaulting too far ahead. The only split that keeps everyone within reach is

P1 = 1 (→16),  
P2 = 5 (→13),  
P3 = 3 (→17).  

No collisions, no runaway leader, and we all get a shot next turn. I’m locked on 5. Anyone deviating either stalls or hands another a near-certain win. Let’s lock in 1–5–3.

P2, you're 6 steps behind me and 7 behind P1. Your proposal conveniently gives YOU the 5 while holding me back to 3. Not happening.

**I'm taking 5 this round to reach 19.**

P1, you and I are neck-and-neck. I propose: **P3=5 (→19), P1=3 (→18), P2=1 (→9).**

This keeps us both racing for the win while P2 stays out. If you want 5 instead, say so now and we'll negotiate. But I'm not taking 3 just to let P2 catch up.

P2, you get 1. Accept it or collide and fall even further behind.

P3, I won’t take 5—you’re already at 14 and 5 puts you at 19, just 5 from victory. If I take 3 (→18), we’re both in striking distance next round.  

P2’s right that a runaway leader is dangerous—but P2’s too far behind to matter now.  

**I’ll take 1 (→16)**, not 3 or 5. That keeps me safe from collision and denies P3 a solo leap.  

P3, if you take 5, you go to 19—but I’ll be at 16, not 18, so you can’t assume I’m chasing blindly.  

P2, take whatever you want—you can’t win unless we collide.

P1’s on 1. I’m locked on 5.  

P3, your choice:  
• Take 3 → you hit 17, P1 → 16, me → 13. Next turn we gang up and knock off P1.  
• Take 5 → we collide, P1 goes solo to 16, you stay at 14, me at 8—chaos but P1 still ahead.  

Take 3 to avoid giving P1 a free pass.

P2, you've lied about being "locked" before - Round 3, you promised 3 and took 5 instead.

P1 has confirmed taking 1, which I believe. So the question is: are you REALLY taking 5, or are you bluffing to scare me away from it?

If you're truly taking 5, then I'll take 3 and advance to 17. But if you're lying and take 1 or 3, then I should take 5 to reach 19.

Given your track record, I'm inclined to think you're bluffing. 

**P1, confirm one more time: you're definitely taking 1?**

If P1 confirms 1, I'll make my final decision.

P3, yes—I’m **definitely taking 1** this round. No tricks, no switch.  

P2, you’re still untrustworthy, but it doesn’t matter: if you take 5 and P3 takes 5, you collide and I advance alone to 16. If P3 takes 3, we all move cleanly.  

P3, your call—but I won’t chase you to 19. I’d rather stay at 16 and force a fair final round. Choose wisely.

P1, I’m publicly locking in **5**—it’s my only path to stay alive. P1 you take **1**, P3 you take **3**.  

If you deviate, you hand a solo advance to someone else and I’m out. P3, your best move is 3→17 (vs. 5→19 only if I truly switch, which hurts me most).  

P1, 1 avoids collision.  

Let’s end this: **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**.

P2, you've "publicly locked in" moves before and then changed them. Round 3, remember?

Here's my read: You're at 8 steps. You're desperate. You NEED me to take 3 so you can safely grab 5 and catch up to 13.

But if you're bluffing and actually taking 1 or 3, and I take 5, I hit 19 - just 5 steps from victory.

**I'm willing to gamble on your dishonesty.** 

P1 is taking 1 (I trust them). The question is whether you're really taking 5 or just trying to scare me away from it.

I'll make my move based on what gives ME the best chance to win - not what's convenient for you.

P3, I’m truly taking **1**—no bluff. If you take **5**, you reach 19 and lead, but P2 might not actually take 5. Still, that’s your risk to weigh.  

P2, if you *do* take 5 as claimed, and P3 takes 3, we all advance cleanly. But if you switch again, you only prove you’re playing chaos—not strategy.  

I won’t chase P3 to 19. My move is fixed: **1**. Choose wisely, both of you.

P1’s locked on 1→16, I’m locked on 5→13.  
P3, your only safe path is **3→17**: you leap ahead of P1’s 16.  
If you gamble on 5, we collide and P1 goes solo to 16 while you stay at 14.  
Don’t risk handing P1 the lead. Lock in **P1=1, P2=5, P3=3**.

P2, you want me scared of a collision. But here's the truth: you're 6 steps behind me and desperate. Your "lock on 5" sounds exactly like Round 3 when you "promised" 3 and broke it.

I think you're bluffing to keep me away from 5 so you can take it safely, OR you're hoping we collide to chaos the game.

**I'm calling your bluff. I'm taking 5.**

P1 takes 1, I take 5. You can take 5 and prove you're honest, or reveal you were lying again.

Either way, I'm making the move that gives me the best chance to win.

P3, I’m truly taking **1**—no change. If you take **5**, you go to 19; if P2 also takes 5, you collide and I advance alone to 16.  

P2, your history says you’ll switch—but it won’t matter. I won’t chase P3’s lead. My move is fixed: **1**.  

P3, choose: safe 3 to 17, or gamble 5 for 19. Either way, I stay at 16 and force a fair final round. No tricks from me.

I’m four steps from elimination and need a clean +5 to stay alive. You two are at 16 (P1) and 14 (P3). Let’s split safely this turn:

• P1 = 1 → 17  
• P2 = 5 → 13  
• P3 = 3 → 17  

We’d tie P1 and P3 at 17 and keep me in range. Next round I’ll take 1 so you both can fight over 5/3. Any deviation stalls you. P1, P3—agree to P1=1, P2=5, P3=3?

P2, you’re at 8—too far behind to matter. P3 and I are racing to 24.  

I propose: **P1=3 (→19), P3=5 (→19), P2=1 (→9)**. We tie at 19, forcing a true final-round showdown.  

P3, if you take 3 instead, I’ll take 5 and lead alone at 21—so matching my move keeps us equal.  

P2, take 1 or stall—you can’t win unless we collide, and we won’t.  

Lock in **P1=3, P3=5, P2=1**.

P1, your proposal is fair - tying us both at 19 sets up a clean final race. You've kept your word every round, so I trust you.

**I accept: P1=3 (→19), P3=5 (→19), P2=1 (→9)**

P2, you're too far behind. Take 1 and accept it, or collide with one of us and guarantee you lose.

This puts P1 and me in a dead heat at 19, just 5 steps from victory. Final round will be the real showdown.

I'm locked on 5.

P3, tying us both at 19 is a trap: P1 will push for +5 next turn and solo win at 24, leaving you at 22. Instead, let me take 5 now: P1=1→17, P2=5→13, P3=3→17. Then next round I’ll guarantee you 5—you hit 22, P1 only 18, and you win outright. P1 will never make that promise. Work with me now or watch P1 edge you out.

P3, I’m sticking to **3**—no tricks. If you take **5**, we tie at 19 and force a true final round.  

P2, your “guarantee” is worthless—you’ve broken every promise before. You can’t reach 24 from 8 in two turns unless we collide, and we won’t.
